results.title: Game Masters: Rob Murray interview
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the ‘Game Masters’ exhibition, Rob Murray speaks about his career as a game designer. Starting out as a solo developer for hire to becoming CEO of Firemint, Murray is one of the most successful indie game developers in existence.

Firemint’s success is due to Murray’s vision to create games such as ‘Flight Control’(2009) and’ Real Racing’ (2009), which are both easy to play and elegant and addictive in equal measure. In addition, his prescient reading of the drive towards personalised gaming, led by the ubiquity of social networking on mobile platforms, has kept his games on trend – ‘Flight Control’, for example, allows players to choose music from their personal libraries to accompany the game.

Rob talks about the rise of mobile based gaming and the development of ‘Flight Control’ and ‘Real Racing’ .

results.title: Game Masters: Hideo Kojima interview
results.brief_description:
Hideo Kojima speaks about his career as a designer and producer of video games at Konami Digital Entertainment and Kojima Productions. At a time when mainstream action games only focused on attack and defeat, ‘METAL GEAR’ (1987) introduced infiltration into the gameplay and became one of the earliest examples of a stealth game. In 1998, the first 3D title in the ‘Metal Gear’ series, ‘METAL GEAR SOLID’, was released, integrating the most advanced stealth-based gameplay yet seen with cut-scenes that reflected Kojima’s passion for cinema. ‘METAL GEAR SOLID’ became a worldwide best seller and was followed by three successful sequels.

NB: This interview was conducted in Hideo Kojima’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Blizzard Entertainment interview
results.brief_description:
Blizzard Entertainment is a world leading developer and publisher renowned for creating some of the industry’s most critically acclaimed games. Blizzard’s first success was in 1994 with ‘Warcraft: Orcs and Humans’, a game that laid the foundations for the burgeoning real-time strategy genre, introducing gameplay features that would become standards. In 1996 the company released the action-role-playing-game ‘Diablo’. With a track record that includes thirteen number one games and multiple Game of the Year awards, Blizzard Entertainment has gone on to establish one of the largest online followings of any game company worldwide.

The company is best known for the subscription-based massively multiplayer online role-playing games ‘World of Warcraft’ (2004), and ‘StarCraft’ (1998) series. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Fumito Ueda interview
results.brief_description:
Fumito Ueda may have only two published games but each one has had such an impact that his influence is felt keenly across the industry. Ueda joined Sony Computer Entertainment in 1997 where he developed his first game, ‘ICO’ (2001), a beautifully poetic adventure game based on an abstracted boy-meets-girl premise. Ueda’s next game, ‘Shadow of the Colossus’ (2005) took an opposing theme to ICO’s sacrificial narrative, with the aim being to topple 16 giant mythical beings to restore the life of a girl named Mono.

NB: This interview was conducted in Fumito Ueda’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Yu Suzuki interview
results.brief_description:
Yu Suzuki talks about his body of work which is one of the most diverse in the industry, ranging from the adrenalin rushes of his early arcade hits ‘Space Harrier’ (1985) and ‘Hang-On’ (1985) to the console adventure epic ‘Shenmue’ (1999).

As the pioneer of immersive, full-body arcade games, Suzuki has never been afraid to explore fantasy, reality and every shade of virtual experience in between.

In 1999, Suzuki moved away from arcades to create ‘Shenmue’ (1999), an open-world adventure for the Dreamcast. ‘Shenmue’ was recognised at the time as one of the most expansive and detailed videogames ever made; it pioneered the ‘open city’ subgenre of open-world games.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Alex Rigopulos and Eran Egozy interview
results.brief_description:
Alex Rigopulos and Eran Egozy talk about their careers designing games at Harmonix Music Systems. While not the first to combine music and videogames, Rigopulos and Egozy were central to the global success of the rhythm genre.

Rigopulos and Egozy’s studio Harmonix’s first two rhythm games, the cult classics ‘Frequency’ (2001) and ‘Amplitude’ (2003), were abstract games with trance-like visuals matched to a gameplay of tight precision. They soon moved on to peripheral-based rhythm games such as ‘Guitar Hero’ (2005), ‘Rock Band’ (2007) and ‘Dance Central’ (2010).

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Phill Ring and Jonathan Smith interview
results.brief_description:
At its inception, TT Games acquired the worldwide rights to LEGO games and began combining the versatility and imagination of LEGO with one of cinema’s more popular worlds to create ‘LEGO Star Wars: The Videogame’ (2005). The unlikely combination of LEGO, ‘Star Wars’ and puzzle-solving gameplay was a surprise hit, garnering acclaim not usually attributed to children’s games.

Continuing the LEGO series, TT Games branched out into a variety of well-known film franchises, including ‘Batman’ and ‘Harry Potter’, creating many entertaining, humorous and beloved titles. With each new title there was an emphasis on improving the formula with new puzzles, gameplay and features.

Producer Phillip Ring and Head of Production, Jonathan Smith, discuss ‘LEGO Star Wars: The Videogame’ series, ‘LEGO Batman: The Videogame’ and ‘LEGO Harry Potter: Years 1-4 & 5-7’.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Tetsuya Mizuguchi interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Tetsuya Mizuguchi started in the industry working for SEGA developing arcade games such as ‘Sega Rally’. In 1994 he was inspired by the street parades in Zurich and soon turned his love of synaesthesia, combining sound and vision, to produce the games ‘Rez’ and ‘Space Channel 5’. Mizuguchi continues to incorporate a notable emphasis on interactive sound design, with his latest game ‘Child of Eden’.

Currently he is co-founder of the videogame development firm Q Entertainment. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Yuji Naka interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Yuji Naka is a videogame designer and programmer, best known as the former head of Sonic Team, where he was the lead programmer of the original ‘Sonic the Hedgehog’. Naka reveals his initial desire to make arcade games and the influence that Yu Suzuki has had on his career as a programmer. Since 2006 he has been the head of Prope, an independent game company he founded after leaving SEGA.
Yuji gives great insights into the development and creation of ‘Sonic the Hedgehog 1 and 2’, ‘Nights into Dreams’ and ‘Chu Chu Rocket’.
NB: This interview was conducted in Yuji Naka’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Paulina Bozek interview
results.creator_credit: ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Paulina Bozek started her career at Ubisoft in Montreal, Canada, before moving to Sony as the Executive Producer of the ‘SingStar’ franchise for PlayStation. Currently she is CEO and co-founder at INENSUA, responsible for overseeing the creative direction and team management for the development of social games and applications. A self-confessed casual gamer, Paulina studied film and communication and has always been interested in pop culture and the combination of technology and entertainment. In this interview she discusses her preference for working on long term projects, as well as the importance of user feedback and engaging the audience early in the development process.

In this interview Paulina talks about ‘SingStar’, ‘Closet Swap’ and her new project ‘Super Fan’. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.
